front.title: New versions of the base DNS RFCs

abstract.t: This document describes the project to update the base DNS RFCs with new and up-to-date documents. It describes the goal, the method and the main choices. The RFC-bis documents themselves are separate documents, not yet published.
It is not intended to be published as a RFC.

REMOVE BEFORE PUBLICATION: this document should be discussed in the IETF DNSOP group, through its mailing list, as long as there is no chartered working group for this project. The source of the document, as well as a list of open issues, is currently kept at Github.

section.title: Introduction and background
section.t: The DNS protocol (, ) is a serious challenge to every implementer or to every engineer who tries to understand it from the reference RFCs. The official standards are very old (almost twenty years), ambiguous on many things, and sometimes obsolete. Both the concepts and the terminology have changed a lot since 1987.

Someone who wants to understand the "official" DNS today has to read not only these official RFCs but also several others that update, patch or precise some aspects of the DNS. This is hardly a satisfying state for a protocol which is so critical. For instance, it allows bad faith actors to have broken name servers, while claiming to be compliant.

Other old protocols managed to consolidate the various documents in a recent set of documents, giving the protocol a solid and modern specification. This is the case with SMTP (), the Internet Message Format () and HTTP ( and friends). It is time to do the same for the DNS.
The goal is therefore to produce two documents, 1034-bis and 1035-bis which will obsolete and , as well as the various RFCs that patch them (such as , or ).
The process is not expected to be an easy or a fast one, it will probably last several years.

The charter of the DNSOP working group, in force at the time of this draft, does not allow such a big change in the base documents of the DNS. Working on this project will probably require a rechartering of the group, or the creation of a new working group. It could be a BoF at IETF 99 in Prague.

section.title: The choices
section.t:
Here are the proposed choices for the project:
No change in the protocol (like it was done for the SMTP or HTTP RFC revisions). Software which was compliant should stay compliant. This goal is not completely realistic: ambiguity in original RFCs (for instance for ENTs) may result in difficulties. We use the RFCs on DNS which are on the Standards track. Use and . DNSSEC will be left alone ( and friends are fine). The terminology will be based on . The goal of the new RFCs will be to describe the protocol, not the operational practices. section.title: Open questions
section.t:
Here are some issues to address before starting the real work:
Should we use the definition of domain names in ? Some RFCs may be integrated in the new RFCs, or could be left alone because they are not mandatory for understanding the DNS but they are so widely useful that one could argue they are part of the base DNS.
